entries.title: Image missing alt attribute
entries.description: Add alt="description" for informative images or alt="" for decorative

entries.title: SVG may need accessibility attributes
entries.description: Add aria-label for meaningful icons or aria-hidden="true" for decorative

entries.title: Click handler on non-interactive element
entries.description: Use <button> for actions or <a> for navigation, or add role="button" tabIndex={0}

entries.title: Clickable div is not keyboard accessible
entries.description: Use <button> instead, or add role="button" tabIndex={0} onKeyDown handler

entries.title: Clickable span is not keyboard accessible
entries.description: Use <button> instead, or add role="button" tabIndex={0} onKeyDown handler

entries.title: Negative tabIndex removes element from tab order
entries.description: Only use tabIndex={-1} for programmatically focused elements

entries.title: Positive tabIndex disrupts natural tab order
entries.description: Use tabIndex={0} or restructure DOM for natural order

entries.title: autoFocus can disorient screen reader users
entries.description: Use sparingly, only for modals/dialogs where focus management is needed

entries.title: Input without id may lack label association
entries.description: Add id and associate with <label htmlFor="id">

entries.title: Icon-only button may lack accessible name
entries.description: Add aria-label="description" or visually hidden text

entries.title: Placeholder is not a substitute for labels
entries.description: Add visible <label> or aria-label for accessibility

entries.title: Color alone used to convey meaning
entries.description: Add icons, text, or patterns alongside color for colorblind users

entries.title: Anchor tag without href
entries.description: Use <button> for actions or add href for navigation

entries.title: Empty href="#" creates navigation issues
entries.description: Use <button> for actions, or provide meaningful href

entries.title: Required: Interactive element missing data-testid
entries.description: Add data-testid="descriptive-name" for testing

entries.title: Required: Icon button should have aria-label
entries.description: Add aria-label="action description"

entries.title: Required: Button missing explicit type attribute
entries.description: Add type="button" to prevent form submission, or type="submit" for forms

entries.title: Required: Component with variants should use cn() for class merging
entries.description: Use cn() from lib/utils for proper Tailwind class merging

entries.title: Required: Reusable component should support ref forwarding
entries.description: Wrap component with React.forwardRef for ref support

entries.title: Keyboard: All interactive components must be keyboard accessible
entries.description: Every interactive element (buttons, links, form controls, tabs, menus) must be operable via keyboard alone. Use native HTML elements (<button>, <a>, <input>) which provide keyboard behavior for free. For custom widgets, add tabIndex={0} for focusability, role for semantics, and onKeyDown for keyboard interaction. Test by navigating the entire UI using only Tab, Enter, Space, Arrow keys, and Escape.

entries.title: Keyboard: Support Tab, Enter, Space, Arrow keys, Escape
entries.description: Five keyboard interactions every component must support: Tab moves focus between interactive elements in DOM order. Enter activates links and buttons. Space activates buttons and toggles checkboxes. Arrow keys navigate within composite widgets (tabs, menus, radio groups, listboxes). Escape closes overlays (modals, dropdowns, tooltips) and returns focus to the trigger element.

entries.title: Keyboard: Provide visible focus indicators
entries.description: Every focusable element must have a clearly visible focus indicator. Use focus-visible:ring-2 focus-visible:ring-primary-500 for a consistent ring that appears only on keyboard navigation (not mouse clicks). Never use outline-none or outline-0 without providing an alternative focus style. Focus indicators must have sufficient contrast (3:1 minimum against adjacent colors per WCAG 2.4.7).

entries.title: Keyboard: Implement proper focus management in overlays
entries.description: Overlays (modals, sheets, dialogs, dropdowns) must implement three focus behaviors: 1) Focus trap — Tab cycles only within the overlay, preventing interaction with background content. 2) Initial focus — move focus to the first focusable element or the close button when the overlay opens. 3) Focus restoration — return focus to the trigger element when the overlay closes. Use a headless UI primitive library to handle these reliably.

entries.title: Screen reader: Use semantic HTML elements
entries.description: Use semantic HTML elements that convey meaning to assistive technology: <nav> for navigation regions, <main> for primary content, <section> with aria-label for distinct page sections, <aside> for complementary content, <header>/<footer> for page/section landmarks. Screen readers use these landmarks for quick navigation. A <div> with onClick is invisible to screen readers — use <button> instead.

entries.title: Screen reader: Provide ARIA labels for icon-only controls
entries.description: Icon-only buttons and controls have no visible text for screen readers to announce. Add aria-label='description' to provide an accessible name. For icons that are purely decorative (next to visible text), use aria-hidden='true' on the icon SVG so screen readers skip it. Every interactive element must have an accessible name — either visible text, aria-label, or aria-labelledby.

entries.title: Screen reader: Announce state changes (loading, errors, success)
entries.description: Dynamic state changes must be announced to screen readers. Use role='status' for non-urgent updates (success messages, progress), role='alert' for urgent interruptions (errors, warnings), and aria-busy='true' on containers during loading to indicate content is being updated. Without these announcements, screen reader users won't know that a form submission succeeded or failed.
entries.example:
Changes saved successfully.
or
Email is required.

entries.title: Screen reader: Use ARIA live regions for dynamic content
entries.description: ARIA live regions announce content changes to screen readers without moving focus. Use aria-live='polite' for non-urgent updates (toast notifications, status messages, search results count) — announced after current speech finishes. Use aria-live='assertive' for urgent updates (error alerts, session expiry warnings) — interrupts immediately. Place the live region in the DOM before the content changes, not at the same time.
entries.example:
Showing {count} results
— updates are announced as count changes.

entries.title: Color contrast: Meet WCAG AA contrast ratios (4.5:1 text, 3:1 UI)
entries.description: WCAG AA requires 4.5:1 contrast ratio for normal text, 3:1 for large text (18px+ or 14px+ bold), and 3:1 for UI components and graphical objects (borders, icons, focus indicators). Always verify contrast ratios before applying color pairs. Same color family requires 400+ shade difference (e.g., PRIMARY[100] on PRIMARY[900] is safe, PRIMARY[300] on PRIMARY[500] is not). Test in both light and dark mode.

entries.title: Color contrast: Don't rely on color alone for information
entries.description: Color-blind users (8% of males) cannot distinguish red/green or other color pairs. Always pair color with a secondary indicator: icons (checkmark for success, X for error), text labels, patterns, or underlines. Form validation must not rely only on red borders — add an error icon and descriptive text. Status badges should include an icon or text prefix, not just a colored dot.
entries.example: Error state: red border + error icon + 'Email is required' text. Status: green dot + 'Active' label.
entries.counterExample: Red border only on invalid fields, colored dots without labels, charts using only color differentiation

entries.title: Color contrast: Provide patterns/icons alongside color coding
entries.description: Charts, graphs, and data visualizations must use patterns (stripes, dots, hatching), different shapes, or direct labels in addition to color. Status indicators should combine color with icons (CheckCircle, AlertTriangle, XCircle). Progress indicators should include percentage text, not just a colored bar. This ensures information is accessible to color-blind users and remains distinguishable in grayscale printing.
entries.example: Chart: blue-solid line + red-dashed line + labels. Status: green CheckCircle + 'Complete' vs red XCircle + 'Failed'.

entries.title: Fitts's Law: minimum touch target size
entries.description: Target size + distance affect interaction time. Application: min-h-11 (44px) for touch targets on mobile
entries.counterExample: Buttons <44px on mobile, Tiny click targets

entries.title: Cognitive Load: reduce unnecessary mental burden
entries.description: Mental effort is finite - reduce unnecessary cognitive burden. Application: Minimize choices, use recognition over recall, maintain context
entries.counterExample: Information overload, Hidden options, Requiring memorization, Dense layouts

entries.title: Keyboard: Tab navigation order must follow visual layout
entries.description: Tab order must follow the visual reading order (left-to-right, top-to-bottom in LTR layouts). Never use positive tabindex values (tabindex='2', tabindex='5') as they create unpredictable jump sequences. Use tabindex='0' to make non-interactive elements focusable when needed, and tabindex='-1' for programmatic focus only (e.g., focusing a heading after navigation). Test tab order by pressing Tab through the entire page — the focus should move logically through the content.
entries.example: Natural order: Logo → Nav links → Main content → Sidebar → Footer. Use tabindex='0' on custom widgets, tabindex='-1' on skip-link targets.
entries.counterExample: tabindex='3' on a button, CSS reordering (order, flex-direction: row-reverse) that breaks tab sequence

entries.title: Keyboard: Enter and Space must activate interactive elements
entries.description: Enter activates links and buttons. Space activates buttons and toggles checkboxes/switches. Native HTML elements (<button>, <a>, <input>) handle this automatically. Custom interactive elements built with <div> or <span> must add role='button', tabindex='0', and onKeyDown handlers for both Enter and Space (preventDefault on Space to prevent page scrolling). Radio buttons and switches should toggle with Space, not Enter.
entries.counterExample: onClick-only <div> elements with no keyboard handler, role='button' without onKeyDown

entries.title: Keyboard: Arrow keys for composite widget navigation
entries.description: Composite widgets (tabs, menus, radio groups, tree views) use arrow keys for internal navigation while Tab moves to the next widget. This is the roving tabindex pattern: one item has tabindex='0' (the active item), others have tabindex='-1'. Arrow keys move the active tabindex. Left/Right for horizontal layouts (tabs, menu bars), Up/Down for vertical layouts (dropdown menus, tree views). Wrap around from last to first optionally. Home/End jump to first/last item.
entries.example: Tab list: Tab moves focus to the tab group, Left/Right arrows switch between tabs, Tab again moves to tab panel content.

entries.title: Keyboard: Escape must close overlays and return focus
entries.description: Escape key must close the topmost overlay (modal, dropdown, popover, tooltip, sheet) and return focus to the element that triggered it. This is critical for keyboard users who would otherwise be trapped. Implement a focus return stack: store the trigger element reference before opening, restore focus on close. For nested overlays (modal containing a dropdown), Escape closes only the innermost layer. Never close the entire page or navigate away on Escape.
entries.example: const triggerRef = useRef(document.activeElement); onClose={() => { close(); triggerRef.current?.focus(); }
entries.counterExample: Modal closes but focus moves to document body, Escape closes all nested overlays at once

entries.title: Screen reader: Use semantic HTML landmarks for page structure
entries.description: Semantic HTML landmarks allow screen reader users to jump between page sections. Use <nav> for navigation (add aria-label when multiple navs exist), <main> for primary content (one per page), <aside> for complementary content (sidebars, filters), <header>/<footer> for page or section chrome, and <section> with aria-label for distinct content regions. Screen readers list all landmarks — users can jump directly to 'Main navigation' or 'Search results'.
entries.counterExample: <div class='nav'>, <div class='main'>, <div class='sidebar'> — invisible to screen reader landmark navigation

entries.title: Screen reader: ARIA live region strategy (polite vs assertive)
entries.description: aria-live='polite' announces after current speech finishes — use for search result counts, form progress, toast notifications, loading completion. aria-live='assertive' interrupts immediately — use for error alerts, session expiry, data loss warnings. The live region element must exist in the DOM before content changes (mount the container on page load, update its content later). role='status' implies aria-live='polite'. role='alert' implies aria-live='assertive'. Avoid adding/removing the live region itself — only change its contents.
entries.example:
Mount:
on load. Update inner text to 'Showing 42 results' on search.
entries.counterExample: Dynamically inserting <div aria-live='assertive'> with content — screen reader may miss it

entries.title: Screen reader: Announce loading, error, and success states
entries.description: Dynamic state transitions must be communicated to screen readers. Loading: use aria-busy='true' on the container being updated, remove when done. Errors: use role='alert' for form validation errors (auto-announces), pair with aria-invalid='true' and aria-describedby pointing to the error message. Success: use role='status' for confirmation messages. Progress: use <progress> element or role='progressbar' with aria-valuenow, aria-valuemin, aria-valuemax.
entries.example:
Loading:
Loading...
. Error:

Invalid email

entries.title: Touch targets: 44x44px minimum on mobile, 36px on desktop
entries.description: WCAG 2.5.8 requires touch targets of at least 44x44px on mobile (min-h-11 min-w-11) and 36x36px on desktop (min-h-9 min-w-9). Spacing between adjacent targets should be at least 8px to prevent accidental taps. For inline links within text, the line-height provides vertical target size. Icon buttons in toolbars are common violators — always apply minimum size even if the icon is visually smaller. Use padding to increase hit area without changing visual size.
entries.example: <button class='min-h-11 min-w-11 p-2 md:min-h-9 md:min-w-9'><Icon size={20} /></button>
entries.counterExample: 24x24px icon buttons on mobile, adjacent actions with no spacing gap

entries.title: Focus indicator: visible ring on keyboard focus, hidden on mouse
entries.description: Keyboard users need a visible focus indicator to know which element is active. Use :focus-visible (not :focus) to show the ring only on keyboard navigation, not on mouse clicks. Standard pattern: focus-visible:ring-2 focus-visible:ring-primary-500 focus-visible:ring-offset-2. Never use outline-none or outline-0 without providing an alternative focus indicator. The focus ring must have at least 3:1 contrast against the surrounding background. For dark backgrounds, use a lighter ring color.
entries.counterExample: outline: none without replacement, :focus instead of :focus-visible (shows ring on mouse click too)

entries.title: Form errors: aria-invalid + aria-describedby + role='alert'
entries.description: Accessible form errors require three connected pieces: (1) aria-invalid='true' on the input to announce it as invalid, (2) aria-describedby pointing to the error message ID so the screen reader reads it when the input is focused, (3) role='alert' on the error message container for immediate announcement when the error appears. Error messages should be specific ('Email must include @') not generic ('Invalid input'). On submit with errors, move focus to the first invalid field.
entries.example: Email must include @ symbol
entries.counterExample: Red border only with no aria attributes, generic 'Error' text with no link to the field, error displayed but not announced
